elements.content: The encapsulation of dyes into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has generated a variety of platforms for luminescence, but little attention has been paid to their application in proton conduction. Here, a cationic MOF {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3]­(NO3)}·(DMA)3·(CH3CN)6·(H2O)30} n (FJU-10, H4L = 4,4′,4″,4‴-(1,4-phenylenbis­(pyridine-4,2,6-triyl))-tetrabenzoic acid, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) was synthesized, and the dye molecule 8-hydroxy-1,3,6-pyrenetrisulfonic acid trisodium salt (HPTS) was further added to the MOF growth solution, but during the reaction, HPTS was nitrated and nitrated HPTS was encapsulated into the FJU-10 to obtain dye@FJU-10. As a result, the intrinsic proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is nearly 5 times higher than that of FJU-10 at 90 °C. Dye@FJU-10 exhibits more sensitive fluorescence quenching toward aniline than FJU-10 in DMF solution (the detection limits of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are as low as 0.58 and 0.62 μM, respectively). Here, it is demonstrated for the first time that intrinsic proton conductivity can be effectively improved by encapsulating a nitrated HPTS dye into an MOF.
elements.clean_text: The encapsulation of dyes into metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has generated a variety of platforms for luminescence, but little attention has been paid to their application in proton conduction. Here, a cationic MOF {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)30} n  (FJU-10, H4L = 4,4',4",4‴-(1,4-phenylenbis(pyridine-4,2,6-triyl))-tetrabenzoic acid, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) was synthesized, and the dye molecule 8-hydroxy-1,3,6-pyrenetrisulfonic acid trisodium salt (HPTS) was further added to the MOF growth solution, but during the reaction, HPTS was nitrated and nitrated HPTS was encapsulated into the FJU-10 to obtain dye@FJU-10. As a result, the intrinsic proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is nearly 5 times higher than that of FJU-10 at 90 °C. Dye@FJU-10 exhibits more sensitive fluorescence quenching toward aniline than FJU-10 in DMF solution (the detection limits of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are as low as 0.58 and 0.62 μM, respectively). Here, it is demonstrated for the first time that intrinsic proton conductivity can be effectively improved by encapsulating a nitrated HPTS dye into an MOF.

elements.content: Proton conduction materials are vital components of proton exchange membrane fuel cells, but commercial Nafion-based electrolytes are limited to large-scale applications due to their high relative humidity, narrow operating temperatures, and freezing damage induced by freeze/thaw cycles. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as emerging electrolyte materials have attracted attention as a promising platform for their adjustable porosity and modifiable features. Although these MOFs exhibited good prospects, it is still a challenge to develop MOFs with high conductivity and wide operating temperature, especially in the sub-zero temperature range. Some practical modifications have been introduced into MOFs for proton conduction; one is to modify the skeleton, such as introducing the sulfonic or free carboxylate group in the skeleton, and the other is to regulate the channels, like loading some proton carriers (e.g., imidazole, H3PO4, and H2SO4) into the pores.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Proton conduction materials are vital components of proton exchange membrane fuel cells, but commercial Nafion-based electrolytes are limited to large-scale applications due to their high relative humidity, narrow operating temperatures, and freezing damage induced by freeze/thaw cycles. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as emerging electrolyte materials have attracted attention as a promising platform for their adjustable porosity and modifiable features. Although these MOFs exhibited good prospects, it is still a challenge to develop MOFs with high conductivity and wide operating temperature, especially in the sub-zero temperature range. Some practical modifications have been introduced into MOFs for proton conduction; one is to modify the skeleton, such as introducing the sulfonic or free carboxylate group in the skeleton, and the other is to regulate the channels, like loading some proton carriers (e.g., imidazole, H3PO4, and H2SO4) into the pores.

elements.content: Dyes are organic molecules with excellent luminescence properties, which are often encapsulated into MOFs or macrocycles as host/guest composites for fluorescence applications. In addition to their good optical properties, some dye molecules with functional groups (e.g., −COOH or −SO3H) can be used as outstanding proton carriers. Dawlaty and Kitagawa doped 8-hydroxy-1,3,6-pyrenetrisulfonic acid trisodium salt (HPTS) into the organic polymers and coordination polymers to enhance photoinduced proton conductivity, respectively, but dye molecules encapsulated into MOFs as proton conduction materials have not been reported yet.
elements.clean_text: Dyes are organic molecules with excellent luminescence properties, which are often encapsulated into MOFs or macrocycles as host/guest composites for fluorescence applications. In addition to their good optical properties, some dye molecules with functional groups (e.g., -COOH or -SO3H) can be used as outstanding proton carriers. Dawlaty and Kitagawa doped 8-hydroxy-1,3,6-pyrenetrisulfonic acid trisodium salt (HPTS) into the organic polymers and coordination polymers to enhance photoinduced proton conductivity, respectively, but dye molecules encapsulated into MOFs as proton conduction materials have not been reported yet.

elements.content: Here, we report an MOF-based material through one-step fabrication of embedding in situ nitrated HPTS into the channels of In­(III)-MOF {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3]­(NO3)}·(DMA)3·(CH3CN)6·(H2O)30} n (FJU-10) (), which shows enhanced intrinsic proton conductivity and fluorescence sensing ability. Dye@FJU-10 displays significantly better intrinsic proton conducting behavior (7.50 × 10–3 σ/cm, 90 °C) and higher sensing ability of aniline (K sv = 5.82 × 104 M–1 and detection limit 0.62 μM) than FJU-10. Their intrinsic proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability are even better than most of the reported MOF materials (Tables S4 and S5). Therefore, loading of suitable dye molecules in MOFs may be a promising path to improve proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report an MOF-based material through one-step fabrication of embedding in situ nitrated HPTS into the channels of In(III)-MOF {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)30} n  (FJU-10) (), which shows enhanced intrinsic proton conductivity and fluorescence sensing ability. Dye@FJU-10 displays significantly better intrinsic proton conducting behavior (7.50 × 10-3 σ/cm, 90 °C) and higher sensing ability of aniline (K sv = 5.82 × 104 M-1 and detection limit 0.62 μM) than FJU-10. Their intrinsic proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability are even better than most of the reported MOF materials (Tables S4 and S5). Therefore, loading of suitable dye molecules in MOFs may be a promising path to improve proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of the Encapsulation of Dyes into FJU-10 via a One-Step Method

elements.content:
It was synthesized by a method similar to previously reported methods.

Synthesis of {{[In<sub>3</sub>OL<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]­(NO<sub>3</sub>)}·(DMA)<sub>3</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>6</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>30</sub>}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>FJU-10</bold>)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol) and In­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h, which afforded bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10. The crystals were collected and air dried. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for FJU-10, C90H147N13O52In3: C 41.77, H 5.73, N 7.04; found: C 40.56, H 5.63, N 7.36. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1): 3051­(w), 2925(s), 1704­(w), 1602(s), 1376(s), 1253­(m), 1171­(m), 1101­(w), 1014(s), 782(s), 586(s), 484(s), 412­(m).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 4,4',4",4‴-(1,4-Phenylenbis(pyridine-4,2,6-triyl))-tetrabenzoic acid (H4L)

It was synthesized by a method similar to previously reported methods. 

Synthesis of {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)30} n  (FJU-10)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol) and In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h, which afforded bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10. The crystals were collected and air dried. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for FJU-10, C90H147N13O52In3: C 41.77, H 5.73, N 7.04; found: C 40.56, H 5.63, N 7.36. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3051(w), 2925(s), 1704(w), 1602(s), 1376(s), 1253(m), 1171(m), 1101(w), 1014(s), 782(s), 586(s), 484(s), 412(m).

elements.content: H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol), HPTS (0.0052 g, 0.01 mmol), and In­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h afforded fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10. The crystals were collected and washed with DMF to remove the dyes on the surface of MOFs. Through the control experiment, the fuchsia is the color of 3-hydroxy-2,5,6,8,9-pentanitro-pyrene-1-sulfonic acid (nitrated HPTS) of HPTS nitrification and the molecular formula is C16H4O14N5S (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for dye@FJU-10, C94.8H144.2N14.2O53.3S0.3 In3: C 42.33, H 5.40, N 7.39, S 0.36; found: C 42.35, H 5.64, N 7.37, S 0.37. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1): 3056­(w), 2935­(w), 1714­(w), 1610(s), 1406 (m), 1307­(m), 1297­(m), 1184­(m), 1178­(w), 1043­(w), 864­(w), 788(s), 742­(m), 703(s), 594­(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)0.7(C16H4O14N5S)0.3}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)28} n  (dye@FJU-10)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol), HPTS (0.0052 g, 0.01 mmol), and In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h afforded fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10. The crystals were collected and washed with DMF to remove the dyes on the surface of MOFs. Through the control experiment, the fuchsia is the color of 3-hydroxy-2,5,6,8,9-pentanitro-pyrene-1-sulfonic acid (nitrated HPTS) of HPTS nitrification and the molecular formula is C16H4O14N5S (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for dye@FJU-10, C94.8H144.2N14.2O53.3S0.3 In3: C 42.33, H 5.40, N 7.39, S 0.36; found: C 42.35, H 5.64, N 7.37, S 0.37. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3056(w), 2935(w), 1714(w), 1610(s), 1406 (m), 1307(m), 1297(m), 1184(m), 1178(w), 1043(w), 864(w), 788(s), 742(m), 703(s), 594(m).

elements.content: Bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10 were obtained by solvothermal reaction of H4L and In­(NO3)3·xH2O in DMA/CH3CN mixed solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed FJU-10 belongs to the cubic space group Pm3̅n, with trimeric [In3O­(COO)6] clusters as the secondary building units (SBUs) (a). The trimeric SBUs are further connected by six independent ligands L to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure, which is isostructural to the Fe–MOF crystal (d). The framework of FJU-10 is cationic, and the disordered NO3 – ions act as counterions. The whole framework contains embedded cubic cages (the dimensions cal. 18.6 Å) and two different types of channels (with or without water molecules suspended in the channels, with sizes of 17.5 × 17.5 and 22.1 × 22.1 Å2, respectively) (c,d), which accounts for 82% of the accessible volume calculation using PLATON software. By elemental analyses, charge balance, and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, the molecular formula of FJU-10 was determined as {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3]­(NO3)}·(DMA)3·(CH3CN)6·(H2O)30} n , in which there are 24 DMA, 48 CH3CN, and 240 H2O molecules per unit cell.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Analysis

Bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10 were obtained by solvothermal reaction of H4L and In(NO3)3⋅xH2O in DMA/CH3CN mixed solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed FJU-10 belongs to the cubic space group Pm3̅n, with trimeric [In3O(COO)6] clusters as the secondary building units (SBUs) (a). The trimeric SBUs are further connected by six independent ligands L to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure, which is isostructural to the Fe-MOF crystal (d). The framework of FJU-10 is cationic, and the disordered NO3 - ions act as counterions. The whole framework contains embedded cubic cages (the dimensions cal. 18.6 Å) and two different types of channels (with or without water molecules suspended in the channels, with sizes of 17.5 × 17.5 and 22.1 × 22.1 Å2, respectively) (c,d), which accounts for 82% of the accessible volume calculation using PLATON software. By elemental analyses, charge balance, and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, the molecular formula of FJU-10 was determined as {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)30} n , in which there are 24 DMA, 48 CH3CN, and 240 H2O molecules per unit cell.

elements.content: Structure of FJU-10: (a) trinuclear In­(III) unit and (b) ligand H4L; (c) a cubic cage in the framework of FJU-10; (d) 3D network in FJU-10.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of FJU-10: (a) trinuclear In(III) unit and (b) ligand H4L; (c) a cubic cage in the framework of FJU-10; (d) 3D network in FJU-10.

elements.content: Inspired by the structural features of FJU-10, we attempted to encapsulate the photosensitive dye molecules HPTS into pores by adding HPTS to the MOF growth solution, and as a result, we harvested the fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10 (). The obtained crystals were washed with DMF to remove dye on the surface of the MOF. By control experiment, we found that the fuchsia is the color of the product of HPTS nitrification. Compared to FJU-10, the color change of the crystal from bright yellow to fuchsia confirms that the dye molecules have successfully introduced into the channels of MOFs. The UV–vis spectrum of the dye@FJU-10 showed a large red shift, and the red shift phenomenon is very similar to the nitrification experiment of HPTS, indicating that the dye molecule of nitrified HPTS does enter the framework (Figures S12 and S13 and Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). As expected, the structure of dye@FJU-10 was characterized by single-crystal X-ray analysis, and its structure was similar to FJU-10; however, owing to the low occupancy and highly disordered nature of the dye, we cannot obtain the detailed location of the dye in the framework by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of dye@FJU-10 is consistent with the simulation and as-synthesis of FJU-10, indicating that the dye molecules were encapsulated into channels of MOFs without changing the framework of FJU-10 (Figure S3). By elemental analyses, charge balance, TG analysis, and control experiments, the molecular formula of dye@FJU-10 was determined as {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3]­(NO3)0.7(C16H4O14N5S)0.3}·(DMA)3·(CH3CN)6·(H2O)28} n , in which there are 2.4 dye, 24 DMA, 48 CH3CN, and 224 H2O molecules per unit cell, indeed the amount of dye molecules embedded at a very low level.
elements.clean_text:
Dye Encapsulation

Inspired by the structural features of FJU-10, we attempted to encapsulate the photosensitive dye molecules HPTS into pores by adding HPTS to the MOF growth solution, and as a result, we harvested the fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10 (). The obtained crystals were washed with DMF to remove dye on the surface of the MOF. By control experiment, we found that the fuchsia is the color of the product of HPTS nitrification. Compared to FJU-10, the color change of the crystal from bright yellow to fuchsia confirms that the dye molecules have successfully introduced into the channels of MOFs. The UV-vis spectrum of the dye@FJU-10 showed a large red shift, and the red shift phenomenon is very similar to the nitrification experiment of HPTS, indicating that the dye molecule of nitrified HPTS does enter the framework (Figures S12 and S13 and Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). As expected, the structure of dye@FJU-10 was characterized by single-crystal X-ray analysis, and its structure was similar to FJU-10; however, owing to the low occupancy and highly disordered nature of the dye, we cannot obtain the detailed location of the dye in the framework by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of dye@FJU-10 is consistent with the simulation and as-synthesis of FJU-10, indicating that the dye molecules were encapsulated into channels of MOFs without changing the framework of FJU-10 (Figure S3). By elemental analyses, charge balance, TG analysis, and control experiments, the molecular formula of dye@FJU-10 was determined as {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)0.7(C16H4O14N5S)0.3}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)28} n , in which there are 2.4 dye, 24 DMA, 48 CH3CN, and 224 H2O molecules per unit cell, indeed the amount of dye molecules embedded at a very low level.

elements.content: The nitrated HPTS also retains the −OH and −SO3H of HPTS and therefore acts as a good proton carrier. In addition, FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are confined to abundant water molecules in the channels, so we can study their intrinsic proton conduction under no additional humidity conditions. The alternating current impedance spectra were applied to characterize the proton conductivity of two compounds from −40 to 90 °C under no additional humidity conditions. The Nyquist plots of two compounds at different temperatures are shown in a,b, S7, and S8. Under sub-zero temperature (−40 °C), the proton conductivities (σ) of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are 3.45 × 10–7 and 3.32 × 10–6 σ/cm, respectively. With temperature increase, the proton conductivity of two MOFs rapidly increases, but the magnitude of the rise is very different. As shown in c, the proton conductivity of FJU-10 is 2.05 × 10–4 σ/cm at 30 °C, whereas the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is 1.25 × 10–3 σ/cm and its conductivity is 6 times higher than that of FJU-10 at the same conditions. At 90 °C, dye@FJU-10 reaches the highest value of 7.50 × 10–3 σ/cm, close to 5-fold higher values than FJU-10 and higher than most MOF conductors under no additional humidity conditions, e.g., [Eu2(CO3)­(ox)2(H2O)2]·4H2O, [Zn­(H2PO4)2(TzH)2] n , ZrP, (Me2NH2)­[Eu­(L)], and FJU-31@Hq3, and comparable to some high-performing MOF conductors, such as HCl⊂(C2N2H10)­(C2N2H9)2Cu8Sn3S12, [ImH2]­[Cu­(H2PO4)1.5(HPO4)0.5·Cl0.5], and FJU-17. These results clearly indicate that the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is higher than that of FJU-10 in the whole temperature range, implying that the dye in the MOF plays an important role in improving the proton conductivity. Based on the concept for photoswitchable proton conducting materials, we further investigated the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 under illumination. Unfortunately, there is no significant change of the ohmic resistance for dye@FJU-10 observed under UV irradiation (Figure S9), which may be due to the low amount of dye in MOF or the loss of photoacidity of nitrified HPTS. Although we did not achieve photoswitchable proton conducting materials, we did succeed in enhancing the intrinsic proton conduction of FJU-10 by encapsulating dye into MOFs. Besides, the direct current conductivity of two MOFs (Figure S11) was tested and found to show very low electronic conductivity (5.87 × 10–10 S/cm for FJU-10 and 3.13 × 10–9 S/cm for dye@FJU-10), indicating that the two MOFs are indeed proton conducting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conduction

The nitrated HPTS also retains the -OH and -SO3H of HPTS and therefore acts as a good proton carrier. In addition, FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are confined to abundant water molecules in the channels, so we can study their intrinsic proton conduction under no additional humidity conditions. The alternating current impedance spectra were applied to characterize the proton conductivity of two compounds from -40 to 90 °C under no additional humidity conditions. The Nyquist plots of two compounds at different temperatures are shown in a,b, S7, and S8. Under sub-zero temperature (-40 °C), the proton conductivities (σ) of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are 3.45 × 10-7 and 3.32 × 10-6 σ/cm, respectively. With temperature increase, the proton conductivity of two MOFs rapidly increases, but the magnitude of the rise is very different. As shown in c, the proton conductivity of FJU-10 is 2.05 × 10-4 σ/cm at 30 °C, whereas the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is 1.25 × 10-3 σ/cm and its conductivity is 6 times higher than that of FJU-10 at the same conditions. At 90 °C, dye@FJU-10 reaches the highest value of 7.50 × 10-3 σ/cm, close to 5-fold higher values than FJU-10 and higher than most MOF conductors under no additional humidity conditions, e.g., [Eu2(CO3)(ox)2(H2O)2]⋅4H2O, [Zn(H2PO4)2(TzH)2] n , ZrP, (Me2NH2)[Eu(L)], and FJU-31@Hq3, and comparable to some high-performing MOF conductors, such as HCl⊂(C2N2H10)(C2N2H9)2Cu8Sn3S12, [ImH2][Cu(H2PO4)1.5(HPO4)0.5⋅Cl0.5], and FJU-17. These results clearly indicate that the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 is higher than that of FJU-10 in the whole temperature range, implying that the dye in the MOF plays an important role in improving the proton conductivity. Based on the concept for photoswitchable proton conducting materials, we further investigated the proton conductivity of dye@FJU-10 under illumination. Unfortunately, there is no significant change of the ohmic resistance for dye@FJU-10 observed under UV irradiation (Figure S9), which may be due to the low amount of dye in MOF or the loss of photoacidity of nitrified HPTS. Although we did not achieve photoswitchable proton conducting materials, we did succeed in enhancing the intrinsic proton conduction of FJU-10 by encapsulating dye into MOFs. Besides, the direct current conductivity of two MOFs (Figure S11) was tested and found to show very low electronic conductivity (5.87 × 10-10 S/cm for FJU-10 and 3.13 × 10-9 S/cm for dye@FJU-10), indicating that the two MOFs are indeed proton conducting materials.

elements.content: Nyquist plots of FJU-10 (a) and dye@FJU-10 (b) at various temperatures under no additional humidity conditions (scatters represent experimental data, and lines do fitting data from equivalent circuits); (c) proton conductivities of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 at −40, 30, and 90 °C under no additional humidity conditions, respectively; (d) Arrhenius plots of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10.
elements.clean_text: 2  Nyquist plots of FJU-10 (a) and dye@FJU-10 (b) at various temperatures under no additional humidity conditions (scatters represent experimental data, and lines do fitting data from equivalent circuits); (c) proton conductivities of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 at -40, 30, and 90 °C under no additional humidity conditions, respectively; (d) Arrhenius plots of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10.

elements.content: To elucidate the possible mechanism of two compounds, the activation energies (E a) of both were estimated using the Arrhenius equation (shown in the Supporting Information). The E a values of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 were calculated to be 0.50 and 0.45 eV, respectively (d). Generally, the behavior of proton conduction can be determined by the value of E a from two mechanisms: the Grotthuss mechanism (E a: 0.1–0.4 eV) and the vehicle mechanism (E a: 0.5–0.9 eV). The E a of FJU-10 is on the boundary of the vehicle mechanism, and the process of proton transport may be coordinated water or lattice water molecules produce proton H3O+ that diffuse into the channels, whereas the other water molecules move in the opposite direction, resulting in a higher activation energy. After the dye molecules were incorporated into FJU-10, introducing the proton carriers (−OH and −SO3H) is helpful for the formation of hydrogen bonds between water molecules and dye molecules to facilitate proton transportation. Two mechanisms in dye@FJU-10 should coexist in the temperature range of −40–90 °C, that is, besides the diffusion of water molecules, the hydrogen bonding formed by dye and water molecules also exists in the channel, which makes them have lower E a and higher conductivity than FJU-10.
elements.clean_text: To elucidate the possible mechanism of two compounds, the activation energies (E a) of both were estimated using the Arrhenius equation (shown in the Supporting Information). The E a values of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 were calculated to be 0.50 and 0.45 eV, respectively (d). Generally, the behavior of proton conduction can be determined by the value of E a from two mechanisms: the Grotthuss mechanism (E a: 0.1-0.4 eV) and the vehicle mechanism (E a: 0.5-0.9 eV). The E a of FJU-10 is on the boundary of the vehicle mechanism, and the process of proton transport may be coordinated water or lattice water molecules produce proton H3O+ that diffuse into the channels, whereas the other water molecules move in the opposite direction, resulting in a higher activation energy. After the dye molecules were incorporated into FJU-10, introducing the proton carriers (-OH and -SO3H) is helpful for the formation of hydrogen bonds between water molecules and dye molecules to facilitate proton transportation. Two mechanisms in dye@FJU-10 should coexist in the temperature range of -40-90 °C, that is, besides the diffusion of water molecules, the hydrogen bonding formed by dye and water molecules also exists in the channel, which makes them have lower E a and higher conductivity than FJU-10.

elements.content: The solid-state emission spectra of H4L, HPTS, FJU-10, and dye@FJU-10 were investigated at room temperature (). FJU-10 exhibits two different broad bands at 385 and 545 nm, which are different from the emission peaks of ligand H4L, mainly attributed to intramolecular and intermolecular electron transitions. The nitrated HPTS is red-shifted by 149 nm compared to the emission peak of HPTS. It is noteworthy that dye@FJU-10 exhibits a strong emission peak at 662 nm, which is highly red-shifted (Δ = 77 nm) with respect to ligand H4L and slightly blue-shifted (Δ = 15 nm) with respect to that for nitrated HPTS. This phenomenon may be due to π···π complexation between the ligand in the skeleton and nitrated HPTS in the channel.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Property

The solid-state emission spectra of H4L, HPTS, FJU-10, and dye@FJU-10 were investigated at room temperature (). FJU-10 exhibits two different broad bands at 385 and 545 nm, which are different from the emission peaks of ligand H4L, mainly attributed to intramolecular and intermolecular electron transitions. The nitrated HPTS is red-shifted by 149 nm compared to the emission peak of HPTS. It is noteworthy that dye@FJU-10 exhibits a strong emission peak at 662 nm, which is highly red-shifted (Δ = 77 nm) with respect to ligand H4L and slightly blue-shifted (Δ = 15 nm) with respect to that for nitrated HPTS. This phenomenon may be due to π⋅⋅⋅π complexation between the ligand in the skeleton and nitrated HPTS in the channel.

elements.content: Fluorescence spectra for H4L (E x = 470 nm), HPTS (E x = 430 nm), FJU-10 (E x = 350 nm), and dye@FJU-10 (E x = 450 nm) in solid, and the nitrated HPTS in DMF.
elements.clean_text: 3  Fluorescence spectra for H4L (E x = 470 nm), HPTS (E x = 430 nm), FJU-10 (E x = 350 nm), and dye@FJU-10 (E x = 450 nm) in solid, and the nitrated HPTS in DMF.

elements.content: Aniline as a typical aromatic amine is an indispensable chemical precursor, widely applied in rubber industries, dyes intermediates, pharmaceuticals, and other fields. However, due to its severe toxicity and suspected carcinogenic properties, once the leakage occurs even at very low concentrations, it will jeopardize environmental security and human health. Therefore, the rapid and efficient detection of aniline is extremely urgent for public security and environmental protection. Considering the excellent and unique fluorescence properties of two MOFs, aniline as an electron donor may affect the interaction between the two MOFs and aniline. The difference of the interaction may provide a means to improve the sensitivity of detecting aniline. Therefore, we tested their ability to detect aniline in DMF by the titration tests. As expected, as the aniline concentration increases, their fluorescence intensity gradually decreases (a,c). The quenching efficiency can be evaluated by the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M] (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of aniline; K sv is the quenching constant (M–1); [M] is the molar concentration of aniline). The SV plots for aniline show a good linear relationship at low concentration, and the plots subsequently deviate from linearity at high concentration, which is likely to self-absorb­(b,d). The K sv constants of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 for aniline are 1.87 × 104 and 5.82 × 104 M–1, respectively. In addition, the detection limits of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are 0.58 and 0.62 μM, respectively, according to 3δ/k. The sensitivities and detection limits for our two materials are comparable with the best materials reported ever (Table S5), and the slight enhancement of the sensitivities and detection limits of dye@FJU-10 may be attributed to the extra interactions between aniline and the introduced dye molecules (Figure S14).

However, due to its severe toxicity and suspected carcinogenic properties, once the leakage occurs even at very low concentrations, it will jeopardize environmental security and human health. Therefore, the rapid and efficient detection of aniline is extremely urgent for public security and environmental protection. Considering the excellent and unique fluorescence properties of two MOFs, aniline as an electron donor may affect the interaction between the two MOFs and aniline. The difference of the interaction may provide a means to improve the sensitivity of detecting aniline. Therefore, we tested their ability to detect aniline in DMF by the titration tests. As expected, as the aniline concentration increases, their fluorescence intensity gradually decreases (a,c). The quenching efficiency can be evaluated by the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M] (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of aniline; K sv is the quenching constant (M-1); [M] is the molar concentration of aniline). The SV plots for aniline show a good linear relationship at low concentration, and the plots subsequently deviate from linearity at high concentration, which is likely to self-absorb(b,d). The K sv constants of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 for aniline are 1.87 × 104 and 5.82 × 104 M-1, respectively. In addition, the detection limits of FJU-10 and dye@FJU-10 are 0.58 and 0.62 μM, respectively, according to 3δ/k. The sensitivities and detection limits for our two materials are comparable with the best materials reported ever (Table S5), and the slight enhancement of the sensitivities and detection limits of dye@FJU-10 may be attributed to the extra interactions between aniline and the introduced dye molecules (Figure S14).

elements.content: In summary, nitrified HPTS was loaded into FJU-10 by a one-step approach, wherein not only its intrinsic proton conductivity is increased by close to 5-fold higher values but also the sensitivities and detection limits of aniline were slightly enhanced. Therefore, loading of suitable dye molecules in MOFs may be a promising path to improve proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability. Further work will be required to unravel the microscopic mechanism leading to enhanced proton conductivity and fluorescence sensitivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, nitrified HPTS was loaded into FJU-10 by a one-step approach, wherein not only its intrinsic proton conductivity is increased by close to 5-fold higher values but also the sensitivities and detection limits of aniline were slightly enhanced. Therefore, loading of suitable dye molecules in MOFs may be a promising path to improve proton conductivity and fluorescence detection ability. Further work will be required to unravel the microscopic mechanism leading to enhanced proton conductivity and fluorescence sensitivity.

cln_elements.content:
It was synthesized by a method similar to previously reported methods.

Synthesis of {{[In<sub>3</sub>OL<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]­(NO<sub>3</sub>)}·(DMA)<sub>3</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>6</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>30</sub>}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>FJU-10</bold>)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol) and In­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h, which afforded bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10. The crystals were collected and air dried. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for FJU-10, C90H147N13O52In3: C 41.77, H 5.73, N 7.04; found: C 40.56, H 5.63, N 7.36. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1): 3051­(w), 2925(s), 1704­(w), 1602(s), 1376(s), 1253­(m), 1171­(m), 1101­(w), 1014(s), 782(s), 586(s), 484(s), 412­(m).

Synthesis of {{[In<sub>3</sub>OL<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]­(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>0.7</sub>(C<sub>16</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>14</sub>N<sub>5</sub>S)<sub>0.3</sub>}·(DMA)<sub>3</sub>·(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>6</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>28</sub>}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>dye@FJU-10</bold>)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol), HPTS (0.0052 g, 0.01 mmol), and In­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h afforded fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10. The crystals were collected and washed with DMF to remove the dyes on the surface of MOFs. Through the control experiment, the fuchsia is the color of 3-hydroxy-2,5,6,8,9-pentanitro-pyrene-1-sulfonic acid (nitrated HPTS) of HPTS nitrification and the molecular formula is C16H4O14N5S (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for dye@FJU-10, C94.8H144.2N14.2O53.3S0.3 In3: C 42.33, H 5.40, N 7.39, S 0.36; found: C 42.35, H 5.64, N 7.37, S 0.37. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1): 3056­(w), 2935­(w), 1714­(w), 1610(s), 1406 (m), 1307­(m), 1297­(m), 1184­(m), 1178­(w), 1043­(w), 864­(w), 788(s), 742­(m), 703(s), 594­(m).

Experimental Section

Synthesis of 4,4',4",4‴-(1,4-Phenylenbis(pyridine-4,2,6-triyl))-tetrabenzoic acid (H4L)

It was synthesized by a method similar to previously reported methods. 

Synthesis of {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)30} n  (FJU-10)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol) and In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h, which afforded bright yellow block crystals of FJU-10. The crystals were collected and air dried. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for FJU-10, C90H147N13O52In3: C 41.77, H 5.73, N 7.04; found: C 40.56, H 5.63, N 7.36. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3051(w), 2925(s), 1704(w), 1602(s), 1376(s), 1253(m), 1171(m), 1101(w), 1014(s), 782(s), 586(s), 484(s), 412(m).

Synthesis of {{[In3OL1.5(H2O)3](NO3)0.7(C16H4O14N5S)0.3}⋅(DMA)3⋅(CH3CN)6⋅(H2O)28} n  (dye@FJU-10)

H4L (0.02 g, 0.03 mmol), HPTS (0.0052 g, 0.01 mmol), and In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMA/CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) mixture solution with the addition of HNO3 at 85 °C for 48 h afforded fuchsia block crystals of dye@FJU-10. The crystals were collected and washed with DMF to remove the dyes on the surface of MOFs. Through the control experiment, the fuchsia is the color of 3-hydroxy-2,5,6,8,9-pentanitro-pyrene-1-sulfonic acid (nitrated HPTS) of HPTS nitrification and the molecular formula is C16H4O14N5S (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for dye@FJU-10, C94.8H144.2N14.2O53.3S0.3 In3: C 42.33, H 5.40, N 7.39, S 0.36; found: C 42.35, H 5.64, N 7.37, S 0.37. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3056(w), 2935(w), 1714(w), 1610(s), 1406 (m), 1307(m), 1297(m), 1184(m), 1178(w), 1043(w), 864(w), 788(s), 742(m), 703(s), 594(m).

metadata.title:
Enhancement of Intrinsic Proton Conductivity and Aniline
Sensitivity by Introducing Dye Molecules into the MOF Channel
